fields.headline: No go, bishop
fields.bodyText: So the Bishop of Rochester thinks multiculturalism gives rise to a "multi-faith mish-mash" (Bishop under fire for attack on Muslim 'no-go areas', January 7). That description rather fits the Church of England, where high and low church have coexisted for ages. The much-anticipated schism between those in favour and those against the ordination of women has also failed to materialise, though I understand some Anglican churches are effectively "no-go areas" for female vicars. If virulently opposed systems of belief are able to survive within his own church, might it also be possible in the country as a whole? Luca Salice London I wonder if Michael Nazir-Ali realises that had the incitement to religious hatred legislation hit the statute books in its original form, he would now be answering a police knock at his door? Alistair McBay National Secular Society
